content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several pieces of tissue stained with H&E, likely representing sections of lymph nodes. There are approximately five distinct tissue fragments, varying in size and shape. They exhibit a dense, basophilic (purple) appearance, which is characteristic of lymphoid tissue. The overall structure appears to be a collection of lymph nodes for staging purposes in a colorectal cancer case.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my task is to screen every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I would systematically examine each piece of tissue. The zoom is on the large lymph node at the bottom left. At low magnification, this area shows some heterogeneity. There are subtle pale or whiter areas within the otherwise uniform dark purple lymphoid tissue. These irregularities can be suspicious for metastatic deposits, necrosis, or sinus histiocytosis, and warrant a closer look at higher magnification to make a definitive diagnosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it shows the interface between two separate tissue fragments. The lower, larger fragment appears to be a lymph node. The smaller fragment directly above it has a dense, uniform, and solid appearance that is suspicious. Zooming in allows me to assess the cytology of this suspicious area and determine if it represents metastatic carcinoma. It is also crucial to examine the relationship between these two fragments to see if they are separate nodes or if there is extranodal extension from one to the other. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. When searching for lymph node metastasis, it is standard practice to systematically examine each lymph node on the slide. The pathologist is zooming into the second lymph node from the top on the left side. The selected area is at the periphery of the node, which includes the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. This is a high-yield area for examination, as metastatic tumor cells often first deposit and grow in the subcapsular sinus after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic examination of each lymph node to detect metastasis. The green box targets the second lymph node from the top, specifically focusing on an area at its periphery. The edge (subcapsular sinus) is a critical region to examine as it's often the first site of metastatic deposits. At low power, this area might have appeared irregular, discolored, or contained a subtle focus of non-lymphoid cells, prompting a closer inspection to rule out malignancy. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node present on the slide. This is the second lymph node from the top. The zoomed-in area is located at the periphery of the lymphoid tissue. I would zoom into this area because the subcapsular sinus, located just under the capsule, is the most common initial site for metastatic cells to deposit. Even at low power, there appears to be a subtle eosinophilic (pink) focus in this region, which is different from the surrounding dense blue lymphoid tissue and warrants closer inspection. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the lymph nodes systematically. This is the third large node from the top. At low power, this specific area appears to have a subtle architectural and color variation; it looks somewhat mottled and less uniformly dark purple compared to other areas. This heterogeneity raises suspicion for an infiltration process, such as metastatic cancer cells disrupting the normal lymphoid tissue, prompting a closer look. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to examine every lymph node thoroughly to check for the presence of metastatic tumor cells. The highlighted area is the second distinct lymph node from the top. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all the tissue fragments on the slide. Even if a node doesn't look grossly abnormal at low power, it must be inspected at high power to rule out micrometastases or isolated tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining all the lymph nodes on the slide. The zoom is on the periphery of the first lymph node from the top right. I chose this area because metastatic cells from a primary tumor often travel through lymphatic vessels and first lodge in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just beneath the lymph node capsule. Therefore, carefully examining the periphery of each lymph node is a crucial first step in ruling out or identifying metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to screen all submitted lymph nodes for evidence of metastatic cancer. The zoom into the top-rightmost lymph node represents the start of a systematic examination of each piece of tissue on the slide. This methodical approach ensures that no area is missed in the search for tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a lymph node parenchyma that is partially replaced by abnormal tissue. The background consists of dense sheets of normal small lymphocytes. However, there are infiltrative, irregular clusters and glands of atypical epithelial cells. These tumor cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. There are also prominent areas of acellular, eosinophilic material and empty spaces, consistent with tumor-associated necrosis. My impression is that this is a lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming it as a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see two distinct tissue fragments. The fragment at the bottom is a lymph node, characterized by the presence of a lymphoid follicle (germinal center) and surrounding lymphocytes, with adjacent adipose (fat) tissue. The fragment at the top is almost completely replaced by a solid, dense sheet of atypical, dark-staining cells with minimal stroma. This morphology is classic for metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that the top fragment is a positive lymph node (or a fragment of one) heavily infiltrated by tumor, while the bottom fragment is a separate, adjacent lymph node that appears negative in this particular field of view. This is a critical finding for cancer staging.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the interface between the lymph node parenchyma and the surrounding perinodal soft tissue. The lower and right portions of the image consist of a dense, monotonous sheet of small, dark-staining lymphocytes, which largely effaces the normal lymph node architecture. The upper left portion shows perinodal tissue, including mature adipose cells (fat) and fibrous connective tissue. In this specific field of view, there are no definite malignant epithelial cells or glandular structures to confirm metastatic carcinoma. However, the complete effacement of the nodal architecture by a dense lymphoid infiltrate is abnormal and requires careful examination of the entire node to rule out metastasis or a lymphoproliferative disorder.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense sheet of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are benign lymphocytes, confirming this is lymph node tissue. There is prominent black pigment, which is likely anthracotic pigment (carbon) from prior drainage, and blue pigment on the absolute edge, which is surgical marking ink. I do not see any clusters of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or features of metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this specific field is a benign lymph node with anthracosis and surface inking. The area was likely investigated to differentiate the pigment from potential tumor cells, and it is negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the architecture of a lymph node. The background consists of a dense population of small, dark lymphocytes. However, filling and expanding the sinuses (the lighter pink, channel-like spaces) are distinct clusters of atypical cells. These cells are much larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, irregular nuclei. They are forming small nests and back-to-back glandular structures. My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma within a lymph node, confirming this as a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view reveals dense sheets of lymphocytes, which is expected in a lymph node. However, there are also infiltrating clusters of atypical, non-lymphoid cells. These cells are larger, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and irregular, enlarged nuclei. They are forming poorly defined nests and glands, which is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, confirming the presence of metastasis from the colorectal primary tumor.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, monotonous population of small, dark, round cells with scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The overall architecture is that of a lymph node. I do not see any atypical glands, nests of large cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, or other features suggestive of metastatic carcinoma in this field. My impression of this specific area is that it is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a dense and polymorphous population of lymphoid cells, including small, mature lymphocytes and some larger, activated lymphocytes. This is characteristic of a reactive lymph node. The fibrous capsule is visible at the top of the image. I do not see any clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or other features that would suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression for this specific field is that of a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. I would proceed to scan the remainder of this node and all other nodes on the slide to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see the architecture of a lymph node with preserved lymphoid follicles. There are multiple, variably-sized lymphoid follicles, some containing paler germinal centers. This pattern is characteristic of follicular hyperplasia, a reactive change. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells that would suggest metastasis. My impression of this specific area is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
